channel.title: Productivity on David John Baker
channel.description: Recent content in Productivity on David John Baker

item.title: Orgflow: System and Tools
item.description: There are several cornerstones of this system. These include: Separate, dedicated locations for each area of responsibility; Separate process for collecting what you have to do, to deciding what this stuff means, to actually doing it; Actionable items that have been indexed by priority, location, urgency; Regular-ish planning of your life at many scales; A disgustingly large reference system for junk.

item.title: Orgflow: Theory
item.description: Many people’s interest in organizational systems is directly proportional to how over-committed they are in the moment.

item.title: Orgflow 6: Notes on Minutes and Communications
item.description: Being good at organization is a blessing and a curse. It’s a blessing as it allows you to feel more in control of what is coming on the horizon.

item.title: Orgflow: 0. Saying No
item.description: As foreshadowed in the introductory post in this series, the orgflow system is not meant to make you more productive.

item.title: Orgflow: How I Work
item.description: We have introduced a new monthly standing meeting at the Music Cognition Group where the focus is meant to be on how to work.

item.title: Personal GTD Categories for Navigating the Day to Day
item.description: After asking Twitter which categories they used to basically “group” together the many “things” in which they have to do, I was mostly met with people (in private) being like “I have no idea even what you are asking”.

item.title: Habit Tracking Success
item.description: It’s important to invest in yourself, regardless of your employment situation.

item.title: To-Dos and Boundaries
item.description: As I write this sentence I know exactly how much time until my next break (45 minutes and 39 seconds if youâ€™re interested).
